Award.AwardTitle: Models for Information Assurance Education and Outreach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops models for information assurance education and outreach that can be disseminated to other institutions. The primary focus areas of this project are a high school outreach program, a multidisciplinary information assurance curriculum, and a community lecture series.

The high school outreach program is a four-week summer program for high school students and high school teachers in two aspects of information assurance - introduction to cryptography and explorations in network security and vulnerability analysis. The purpose of the outreach program is to introduce self-exploratory projects to students who have never participated in a research project and to encourage participating teachers to disseminate the ideas back to their classrooms during the school year. This program will help cultivate interest in information assurance.

The proposed multidisciplinary information assurance curriculum incorporates computer science, mathematics, political science, criminal justice, and other related fields to build a strong program that addresses both the technical and social aspects of information assurance. Developed in consultation with faculty of the respective departments and with members of the law enforcement and intelligence communities, the intent of the curriculum is to create well-rounded graduates with a broad base of knowledge.

The community lecture series addresses the lack of information assurance education channels in the region. The annual free community course provides in-depth exposure to information assurance topics, with culminating lectures featuring regional and national speakers. The proposed activity is a model for community engagement and education which will raise community awareness of information assurance issues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program increased the capacity for information assurance education at California State University, Bakersfield (CSUB) and developed modules that can be disseminated on a regional and national scale. The goal was to increase interest in the information assurance field and to increase the capacity for high-quality education. 

The primary objectives of the grant were to increase interest in information assurance related undergraduate degrees through a high school outreach activity and to increase the rate of undergraduate students pursuing graduate degrees or careers in information assurance through a multidisciplinary information assurance program.

The high school outreach program was a four-week, all-day program where the high school students came on to the CSUB campus and participated in hands-on activities related to cryptography and cyber security. A diverse population of students, reflecting the demographics of the Kern County region, participated in the summer program. Pre- and post-surveys were used to measure changes in attitudes towards college in general and information assurance majors in particular. Students reported an increase in interest in attending college and an increase in interest in cyber security as a result of participating in the program. Additionally, 21.5% of the participants are now pursuing college degrees at CSUB, primarily in computer science and mathematics.

The multidisciplinary information assurance program consisted of developing an information security concentration in computer science and creating an undergraduate student research program. The information security concentration is built around a traditional computer science core, but also requires cognate courses in global intelligence and national security. The curriculum has been developed for both a quarter system and a semester system. The concentration was added at CSUB in Fall 2013 and the first two graduates are on track to graduate in Spring 2016. Both of these students were accepted into national internships in cyber security in the summer of 2015. The undergraduate research students have won awards at local, regional, and national undergraduate research competitions. Two of the three research students who have graduated are pursuing graduate degrees in national intelligence or computer science.

Intellectual Merit: The summer high school outreach activity has been disseminated at the local and national level, so that other institutions can use the activity as a model for their own outreach activities. The information assurance curriculum and undergraduate research program has transformed the study of information assurance, global security, and national intelligence at CSUB into a multidisciplinary, synergistic effort. It is available in both quarter system and semester system format for other institutions to use as a model for their own curriculum.

Broader Impact: The summer outreach program for high school students attracted a diverse population of students and has had a strong positive impact on their interest in pursuing college education in general and information assurance education in particular. The information security concentration has produced undergraduate students who are competitive on a national level for information assurance careers.
